content: I wouldn't do it that way. I would add a new account for the new host, leaving the old one as is. Once I'm sure the new account is working properly, I can copy (safest) or move the old mail from the old account's folders to new folders (including the Inbox, if you want) on the new host, or local folders.
creator: rednoise

content: Lin, I will try this. I didn't even realize I could copy folders, but sure enough, I see that option in Thunderbird. I will be changing the MX, SPF, and DKIM text records in 2-3 days and once set, will try that afterwards. This sounds so great, thanks much. Chuck
creator: chuckwb9

content:
Yes, but you have to deal with this. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/dedicated-profile-thunderbird-installation

You also need to be aware that each version contains many bug fixes and security fixes. https://www.mozilla.org/en-US/security/known-vulnerabilities/thunderbird/

Going backwards is largely asking for trouble, hence many like myself remain on the ESR release which updates once a year, gets those security fixes and does not have as many issues with addons not being updated before the monthly release makes it obsolete.

You actually get to choose to use/download the ESR version here https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/all/ the big bold download button on the main page will always offer the monthly release.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
FIXED

1. Close Thunderbird: Make sure the application is completely closed.

2. Locate your Profile Folder: C:\Users\[Your_Username]\AppData\Roaming\Thunderbird\Profiles\

3. Find the profiles.ini file: Inside your Thunderbird profiles directory, locate the profiles.ini file. This file lists all your Thunderbird profiles.

4. Find the correct profile folder: The profiles.ini file will show you the name of your profile folder, which is typically a string of random letters and numbers followed by .default-release (e.g., abcdefgh.default-release). Go into that folder.

5. Delete the residual information in the file: Inside your profile folder, look for a file named prefs.js (BACKUP FIRST) and open it with a text editor. Search for your email address or the domain of your email provider. You are looking for a line that starts with something like user_pref("mail.server.serverX.hostname", ...); where X is a number. This line holds the incoming server information that is causing the conflict. Carefully delete the entire block of lines related to your email account. It will be a set of lines with mail.server.serverX and mail.account.accountX that match your email. If you're not comfortable editing the file, you can try deleting the entire file, but this will reset other preferences as well.

My X = 3 user_pref("mail.server.server3.check_new_mail", true); user_pref("mail.server.server3.clientid", … user_pref("mail.server.server3.directory", … user_pref("mail.server.server3.directory-rel… user_pref("mail.server.server3.hostname", … ...

Best regards, Jose
creator: jose_ze

content: Thunderbird uses the term "Junk" not spam for pop mail accounts. The relevant folders will be created on demand. If you don't have one, mark some mail as junk and you will.
creator: MattAuSupport

So POP mail accounts use "Junk", I marked some mails, the folder does not show, yet.

What do I have to do to see it?

Thank you for the prompt response.

Jean-Pierre
creator: dareys

content:
As Thunderbird simply does not offer mail accounts, anything you add will by definition have to already exist. Like so many stupid things in computing Thunderbird used to try an make an delineation between the accounts that were offered as "new" under a commercial arrangement and those that you already have. As that relationship has apparently ended, the links in the menu no longer exist, there is nothing to delineate. I doubt a great deal of though went into the change as the Project will be offering it's own "New" email addresses as a part of the Thundermail initiative so another batch of changes are only a matter of a short time away.

So use the menu

or you might use the New account button in account settings.

Neither creates a new email address, only being able to add an existing email account to the mail client.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Forse è stato attivato il nuovo Centro account che tende a bloccarsi se non riconosce le impostazioni. Lo puoi disattivare da

Menu > Impostazioni > Generale Sezione Centro account Togli la spunta da Crea account nel nuovo Centro account

A questo punto puoi usare la vecchia procedura automatica -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/configurazione-automatica-account

o la procedura manuale -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/configurazione-manuale-account
creator: @next

content:
Ti ringrazio veramente tanto per la risposta! Nel frattempo colto dalla disperazione avevo iniziato a aprire ogni singolo menù a tendina e sotto menù alla ricerca di nulla di preciso, cercavbo risposte.... e confermo che era proprio come dicevi tu, tolto il flag dall apgina impostazioni Account, ho potuto svolgere la normale procedura e ho installato il client di posta nuovamente.

content:
Aggiornamento automatico e manuale? A quando risale l'ultimo backup?

Inoltre Per poter inquadrare il problema prova a fornire queste informazioni:

  1. Versione di Thunderbird
  2. Versione del sistema operativo
  3. Provider delle caselle email (Gmail, Libero, Hotmail, etc.)
  4. Tipologia di account (POP3, IMAP)
  5. Estensioni installate
  6. Messaggi di errore che vengono visualizzati durante l'utilizzo di Thunderbird
  7. Software di sicurezza eventualmente presenti (Antivirus e simili)
  8. Screenshot del problema (se utile a chiarire il contesto)
creator: @next

content: Probabile che il server su cui si trova la sua casella abbia una nomenclatura non standard delle cartelle per cui Thunderbird non può mappare con i nomi predefiniti. A livello pratico non c'è differenza tra le due. Però per lo stesso account le mail inviate dovrebbero finire sempre nella stessa cartella.

content: It's a current limitation of the built-in CardDAV: labels (mailing lists) aren't supported. CardBook supports all versions of TB, but the label sync. with Google Contacts should be tested to confirm 2-way sync. is working.

content:
Tools | Account Settings | + New Account | Mail Account

That fires up a Wizard that will prompt you for the basic information. It queries its own database of known email hosts and will probably be able to fill in the necessary (IMAP/POP and SMTP) server settings. It would be best if you come armed with that information, just in case you need it.

content:
This forum is for Thunderbird users helping other Thunderbird users. Nobody here has any control over you email accounts or can check them for you.

If you're receiving all other mail as normal, and you don't find the missing messages in your Spam folder, I'd guess that the problem is on Bloomberg's end, or your mail ISP is erroneously blocking them. In either case, Thunderbird isn't the problem.
creator: rednoise

content: Click on the down arrow to allow you to set the <N> <minutes| hour> and scroll down to the very end and click on custom
